newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong economy seen robust despite challenges.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong economy seen robust despite challenges.

text.p: Hong Kong, the city that prospered by living off its wits, should remain competitive well into the future despite a welter of outstanding challenges, the authors of a new book said on Thursday.

"Hong Kong faces a number of challenges, including rising costs and competition from other regional centres, and - of course - the transition to Chinese rule, but the intrinsic strength of the Hong Kong economy makes it robust even to fairly major shocks," Michael Enright, one of three authors of "The Hong Kong Advantage" told a news conference.

Hong Kong's history of prospering despite the odds combined with a harmonious balance between business and government, local and overseas firms, management and enterprise should ensure a strong future, said joint author Edith Scott.
"Our research identified several reasons why Hong Kong has been and is likely to remain the world's quintessential business city," she said.
Hong Kong prospered in part by keeping its economy open, allowing information to flow freely and letting markets rather than bureaucrats set the tone, Enright said.
The result is a teeming metropolis marked by ingenuity and a can-do business attitude, where many entrepreneurs count pagers and cellular telephones as their only fixed assets.
Hong Kong's willingness to seize opportunity and adapt its capabilities to exploit those opportunities bode well for the future, Enright said.
However, Hong Kong's population of 6.4 million residents is increasingly geographically stable, implying more home-grown brands and a much greater investment in fixed assets.
Hong Kong's tradeable economy also accounts for a smaller proportion of the territory's overall economy.

Services now make up for a rising 80 percent of gross domestic product while manufacturing has slumped to nine percent of GDP from 23 percent over the past decade, said joint author David Dodwell, a director at Jardine Fleming.
This shift is forcing a number of monopolies and oligopolies in the territory's non-traded economy - such as telecommunications companies - to open up to competition.

"In the past, Hong Kong was so much more competitive it could live with these inefficiencies...(but) if Hong Kong's non-traded economy does not liberalise faster, does not become more competitive, it will be at the peril of the economy," Dodwell warned.
The risk that the transition to Chinese rule does not go smoothly ranks first as the greatest near-term risk to the territory's competitiveness, Enright said.

External challenges, such as the risk that the United States fails to renew China's Most Favoured Nation status, a series of trading perks that boost Sino-U.S. trade routed through Hong Kong, also pose a threat.

But Enright said educating the future workforce could soon become the greatest "constraint" to Hong Kong's economy. The territory's workforce is becoming younger and less transient and will require aggressive training, he said.
"I wouldn't call it a threat. I would call it a constraint over the medium term," he said.
Hong Kong also faces mounting competition from other centres such as Singapore and Taiwan, which have actively targetted multinationals and industries in which Hong Kong held an edge.
